data.Title: Knowledge Into Action
data.Location: Bucksbaum 131 - Grinnell College Museum of Art
data.Description: Each year, objects from the Museum’s art collection serve as inspiration for Grinnell College students for discussion, research, writing, art making, and exhibition projects. Knowledge into Action features artworks that have enriched the learning experience for Grinnell College students who have gone on to have careers in museums and the arts. This exhibition is presented in celebration of the 25th anniversary of Grinnell College’s Bucksbaum Center for the Arts.

data.Title: Summer Independent Projects Workshop
data.Description:
Want to develop skills, gain experience, and tailor it to your specific interests? An independent project might be perfect for you! All class years and all majors welcome.


  Dani Perkins and Destini Ross of the CLS will discuss how to develop an independent project, best practices, and generate ideas. This is a great option if you don’t have a formal summer experience lined up, or have a gap this summer between experiences you want to fill with something meaningful.


  Register on Handshake at: Summer Independent Projects Workshop | Handshake


  Email Destini Ross, Associate Director; Arts, Media and Communications Career Community in the Center for Careers, Life and Service for questions or accommodations.

data.Title: Vessel, a film by Diana Whitten, 2014.
data.Description:
Dr. Rebecca Gomperts sails a ship around the world, providing abortions at sea for women with no legal alternative. Her idea begins as flawed spectacle, faced with governmental, religious, and military blockade. But with each roadblock comes a more refined mission, until Rebecca realizes she can use new technologies to bypass law - and train women to give themselves abortions using WHO-researched protocols with pills. From there we witness her create an underground network of emboldened, informed activists who trust women to handle abortion themselves. Vessel is Rebecca’s story: one of a woman who hears and answers a calling, and transforms a wildly improbable idea into a global movement.


  This film is 90 minutes and has English subtitles.


  This event is not intended for minors


  Read more on the film website, or watch a trailer.

data.Title: Campus Forum
data.Description:
This forum will provide an opportunity to review and discuss the promise and protections of academic freedom and the pressure points of the current moment.  You can find resources for this topic on Academic Freedom & Free Expression tab of the Campus Forum Sharepoint site. 


  The format of the Campus Forums will be a short presentation followed by discussion of submitted questions followed by time for question from the audience.  Please submit your question for forums through this qualtrics form.  By having a robust set of questions and concerns in advance we can plan our time to best ensure that we are able to cover the topics of interest to the campus in each forum.

data.Title: Rosenfield Program Event
data.Description: Our speaker is a national investigative reporter for The Washington Post who was on a team that won a Pulitzer Prize last year for the series “American Icon”––which, in the Pulitzer Board’s words,  was a “sobering examination of the AR-15 semi-automatic rifle, which forced readers to reckon with the horrors wrought by the weapon often used for mass shootings in America.”  This project built on Foster-Frau’s earlier work as a reporter for The San Antonio Express-News, where she covered immigration and border affairs and was the leader reporter on the Sutherland Springs mass shooting in 2017. Foster-Frau’s more recent reporting deals with immigration and includes articles with headlines like “Private prison firms prepare to reopen closed facilities to hold immigrants” and “Invasive frisks, suicide attempts: Three migrants describe Guantánamo detention.” Earlier this month, she participated in a live chat at the Post on the theme “Are there any checks and balances on Trump at this point?”

data.Title: Information Session
data.Description: Epic is a healthcare software company headquartered in Madison, WI, with customers in all 50 states and even internationally. We design, build, and implement applications for everything from hospital scheduling to supporting medical specialties to hospital billing. About 78 percent of the US population is cared for by Epic software!

data.Title: Just Talk!: Underground Reads
data.Description:
Just Talk!: Underground Reads is a combination of an information session on the state of censorship in Iowa, presented by Annie’s Foundation, a non-profit organization, followed by a panel of educators to discuss the impact of censorship on the LGBTQ community.


  Annie’s Foundation is a grassroots organization based out of Johnston, IA, whose mission is to ensure that community members have access to books with characters and subjects that reflect the diversity and complexity of the world around them.  Annie’s Foundation hands out banned and challenged books at events all over the state of Iowa and is planning on handing out books at the conclusion of the educators’ panel. The educators’ panel includes teachers of varying positionalities: members of the LGBTQ+ community, teachers from elementary and secondary schools, sponsors of GSA’s, and plaintiffs in the lawsuit against SF496 (the book banning law in Iowa).

data.Title: Aikido
data.Description: Aikido Practice: Aikido is a Japanese martial art dedicated to resolving conflict as peacefully as possible. It uses unified body motion, rather than upper body strength, to throw, lock, or pin attackers. We are affiliated with the United States Aikido Federation, and rank earned at Grinnell is transferrable to other dojos in our organization. Beginners are welcome to start at any time (just wear comfortable clothes).

data.Title: CLS Peace Corps Alumni Info Session
data.Description:
Join the CLS and its Education Professions + Career Community to welcome alumni Jeanette Au ’16, current Program Manager at the Center for Volunteer and Nonprofit Leadership in the San Francisco Bay Area, to discuss her previous 3-year-long service term as a Peace Corps volunteer.


  Students will hear about her experience as a long-term volunteer and have the opportunity to ask Jeanette questions regarding the Peace Corps application process, expectations for a Peace Corps service term, among many other topics. Lunch will NOT be provided, but please feel free to bring your own to the session.


  Please register via the following Handshake link: grinnell.joinhandshake.com….


  Please email Chad Berman, the Director of the Education Professions + Career Community in the CLS, at bermanch@grinnell.edu with any questions.
data.Org: Center For Careers Life And Service

data.Title: Scholars’ Convocation: LeAnne Howe
data.Description:
“My life in Amman Jordan during the Arab Spring of 2010-2011 gave me a perspective on colonization, the ‘will to power’ and how one man’s sacrifice in Tunisia really did change the region. For the past 14 years I’ve tried to consider all that I witnessed as a stranger in a foreign land. A Choctaw In King Abdullah’s Court, a memoir, aims to capture the humor, and often despair of being alone among a sea of indigenous peoples that only know of American Indians as cartoons, or dead heroes.”


  LeAnne Howe is Eidson Distinguished Professor at the University of Georgia. She has published award-winning work in multiple genres spread out across a global network in which she connects literature, Indigenous knowledge, Native histories, and expressive cultures. She received her MFA from Vermont in 2000.


  The usual constraints of time and space do not allow us to do justice to Howe’s prolific output, an output that pushes back exuberantly against the very configurations that seek to pin her to specific locations and locutions. Listing Howe’s awards alone is obviously insufficient, but doing so might give us a sense of the responsibility we readers and fellow academics share to pay proper respect to the enormity of her gifts: Howe shares a Native and Indigenous Studies Association (NAISA) award for literary criticism with eleven other scholars for Reasoning Together: The Native Critics Collective, named one of the ten most influential books of the first decade of the twenty-first century for indigenous scholarship, 2011; Howe is also the recipient of a United States Artists (USA) Ford Fellowship, Lifetime Achievement Award by the Native Writers’ Circle of the Americas, and the American Book Award and Oklahoma Book Award for Shell Shaker (2001); in October 2015, Howe received the Distinguished Achievement Award from the Western Literature Association, and in 2014 she received the Modern Languages Association inaugural prize for Studies in Native American Literatures, Cultures, and Languages, for her short story collection, Choctalking on Other Realities; I Fuck Up in Japan, a story from the collection has been reprinted in many journals; and a special issue of Studies in American Indian Literature (2014) contains an exploration by six scholars on Howe’s literary concept of Tribalography; Howe was also a Fulbright Distinguished Scholar to Jordan, with that experience serving as the backdrop for her talk.

data.Title: Writing Through Conflict
data.Location: HSSC N1168 - McMurray Family Academic Classroom
data.Description:
In the “middle of everywhere”,  Grinnellians are often feeling split between where we live and where we are from. Writing Through Conflict provides a safe space for reflective writing and artistic expression to help bridge the gap. Each session will give Students, Staff and Faculty the opportunity to write and share as they choose.
  Questions? [persiana@grinnell.edu] [yookayeo@grinnell.edu]
  Sponsored by the Peace and Conflict Program

data.Title: STEM Outside the Research Lab
data.Description:
Chae Jeon ’17 majored in biological chemistry at Grinnell and holds a PhD in chemistry from the University of Michigan. She currently works as a patent analyst at Chemical Abstracts Service. In this seminar, Chae will share how her research led to a career in intellectual properties, various career paths in intellectual property, and her experience in pursuing a career in a nonprofit organization.


  While at Grinnell, Chae conducted MAP research under Professor Elaine Marzluff while teaching Korean as an ALSO instructor. With her interest in foreign languages and teaching, Chae took the opportunity to teach in Japan at a STEM-focused high school for a year as a participant of the Japan Exchange and Teaching (JET) Program after graduation. She returned to the States to continue pursuing her passion in chemistry and completed her PhD in chemistry at the University of Michigan followed by postdoctoral research position at the University of Oregon.
data.Org: Center For Careers Life And Service

data.Title: Circle Gathering
data.Description:
Are you walking a Pagan Path?


  Are you drawn to nature-centered spiritual practices?


  Are you curious to learn more?


  Come to Circle Gathering!


  Circle is a space for those who are interested in exploring pagan or nature-centered spiritual paths. We will spend our time together discussing texts and beliefs, sharing practices, walking in nature, meditating, drumming, and more.


   Our Gatherings will take place on Thursdays at 4:00 pm in the CRSSJ Prayer Garage


  Circle Gathering is led by Carolyn Herbst Lewis. For more information or for spiritual discussion, email Carolyn at [lewiscar].

data.Title: CS Extras
data.Description: Join the Computer Science department this spring for some Extra enjoyment! This semester the CS department will host various talks and guests on Thursdays in Noyce 3821.

data.Title: Writing Workshop: LeAnne Howe
data.Description:
Join Choctaw writer LeAnne Howe for a writing workshop and discussion on playwriting and multiple genres. While focusing on writing for stage, opera, and film, Howe will also connect her craft in writing poetry, novels, and memoir about her life as an Indigenous artist and scholar. Snacks will be provided.


  LeAnne Howe, Eidson Distinguished Professor at the University of Georgia, connects literature, Indigenous knowledge, Native histories, and expressive cultures in her work. Her interests include Native and indigenous literatures, performance studies, film, and Indigeneity.


  For further information, contact Prof. Jen Shook at shookjen@grinnell.edu.
data.Org: Center For The Humanities, Theatre Dance Department, Writers At Grinnell

data.Title: Forest Bathing
data.Location: Off Campus - See EVENT DESCRIPTION for Location
data.Description: Forest bathing is the practice of taking in the natural environment though all of one’s senses. Each Thursday at 4:30pm SHAW will be leading students on a forest bathing experience. Sign-ups are required at https://forms.office.com/r/K92EGG2LD3.  Effects of forest bathing on health promotion and disease prevention in the journal Environmental Health and Preventive Medicine indicates that it increases cells that prevent cancer, reduces blood pressure, reduces stress hormones, balances the autonomic nervous system, improves sleep, and helps with insulin sensitivity. It reduces stress, anxiety, depression, anger, fatigue, and confusion. It increases the sense of vigor, thus preventing the effects of depression. There is even evidence that it may prevent the effects of COVID-19 by boosting immune function and reducing mental stress.

data.Title: Teaching a Stone to Talk
data.Description:
In collaboration with the Center for Religion, Spirituality, & Social Justice (CRSSJ), the Department of Residence Life is excited to invite you to join us for an exciting opportunity to explore spirituality in community with others.


  Join CRSSJ’s Rabbi Sarah Brammer-Shlay and Rev. Cassandra Lawrence for engaging discussions on spirituality. Connect with fellow students, reflect on your spiritual wellness, and explore how it impacts your overall well-being. Enjoy light snacks and a simple DIY craft to take home!
